name: Kadhi Pakora
history: Kadhi Pakora, a popular North Indian dish, is part of the rich culinary heritage of India. It's a comfort food for many, combining the tangy taste of Kadhi with the delightful crunch of Pakoras.
description: Kadhi Pakora is a creamy, yogurt-based curry with gram flour (besan) and spices, featuring deep-fried vegetable fritters (pakoras) soaked in it. It's known for its sour and savory flavor, often served with rice.

equipment.name: pan
equipment.description: For making the kadhi and frying pakoras.

instructions.title: Prepare the Pakoras
instructions.description: Mix onions, spinach, potatoes, a portion of gram flour, red chili powder, and salt. Add water to make a thick batter. Heat oil and deep-fry spoonfuls of the batter until golden. Drain and set aside.

instructions.title: Make the Kadhi
instructions.description: Whisk yogurt with the remaining gram flour, turmeric powder, and water to form a smooth mixture. Heat a little oil, add cumin seeds, fenugreek seeds, asafoetida, and crushed coriander seeds. Pour in the yogurt mixture and bring to a boil. Simmer until it thickens.

instructions.title: Combine Pakoras with Kadhi
instructions.description: Add the fried pakoras to the kadhi. Simmer for 5-10 minutes so the pakoras soak up some of the kadhi.

instructions.title: Garnish and Serve
instructions.description: Garnish with chopped cilantro. Serve hot with steamed rice or Indian bread.

tips: Ensure the kadhi is not too runny or too thick; adjust the consistency with water as needed.
The pakoras should be crispy on the outside and soft inside.
variations: Add different vegetables like cauliflower or bell peppers to the pakoras.
For a tangier kadhi, add a little tamarind paste or amchur (dry mango powder).

storage.shelfLife: Can be refrigerated for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat on the stove or in a microwave until hot.
presentationTips: Serve in a traditional Indian bowl, with a side of lemon wedges.
Pair with plain basmati rice or a simple jeera (cumin) rice.
